If the patients are the same, that establishes the linkage. There's also an extension that allows direct linkage to a 'study' from any resource - if the source system has actually established such a linkage.

element.name: Subject Identifier for the Study

cdisc.label: SUBJID
cdisc.definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.

cdisc.label: DM.SUBJID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Subject identifier, which must be unique within the study. Often the ID of the subject as recorded on a CRF.

definition.value: Identifiers assigned to this research subject for a study.

element.comment:
Study subject is found by finding the StudySubject that corresponds to the same Patient and ResearchStudy as the Procedure.
No standard way to decide which subject identifier to use

element.name: Any Procedures Performed

cdisc.label: PRYN
cdisc.definition: An indication whether or not the subject had any procedures performed.

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM aCRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED

element.gap: In FHIR, this would be determined by searching for Procedures with a given subject (possibly also filtered by research study) and excluding those that were entered in error. It might also be necessary to search for education, massage, cognitive therapy and various other data to determine all procedures.

element.name: Procedure Category

cdisc.label: PRCAT
cdisc.definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.

cdisc.label: PRCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Used to define a category of procedure values.

definition.value: A code that classifies the procedure for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").

element.comment: FHIR doesn't have 2 distinct category levels. The option exists to have as many categorizations with whatever axes and granularities needed or desired. When mapping data to a particular study, it would be necessary to decide what category values best correspond to CAT vs. SCAT. A standard extension will be needed to convey multiple repetitions in R4. (Procedure.category does repeat in the draft of R5) The SNOMED binding is an example, which means that any codes can be used. Even if the binding were stronger, alternate codes would be possible on other repetitions.

element.name: Procedure Subcategory

cdisc.label: PRSCAT
cdisc.definition: A sub-division of the PRCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.

cdisc.label: PRSCAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Used to define a further categorization of PRCAT values.

definition.value: A code that classifies the procedure for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").

element.comment: FHIR doesn't have 2 distinct category levels. Instead, Procedure.category repeats. The option exists to have as many categorizations with whatever axes and granularities needed or desired. When mapping data to a particular study, it would be necessary to decide what category values best correspond to CAT vs. SCAT.

cdisc.label: PRSPID
cdisc.definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, This is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.

cdisc.label: PRSPID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Sponsor-defined identifier. Example: pre-printed line identifier on a CRF or record identifier defined in the sponsor's operational database.

definition.value: Business identifiers assigned to this procedure by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and is propagated from server to server.

comment.value: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and Person resource instances might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: Reported Name of Procedure

cdisc.label: PRTRT
cdisc.definition: The verbatim surgical, therapeutic, or diagnostic procedure's name.

cdisc.label: PRTRT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Name of procedure performed, either pre-printed or collected on a CRF.

definition.value: The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure cannot be coded (e.g. "Laparoscopic Appendectomy").

element.comment: The name as expressed by or displayed to the user goes in code.text. The name associated with the selected code goes in code.coding.display.

element.name: Standardized Procedure Name

cdisc.label: PRDECOD
cdisc.definition: The dictionary- or sponsor-defined standardized text description of PRTRT, or the modified topic variable (PRMODIFY), if applicable.

cdisc.label: PRDECOD
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Standardized or dictionary-derived name of PRTRT. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms in the define.xml external codelist attributes. If an intervention term does not have a decode value in the dictionary then PRDECOD will be null.

definition.value: The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure cannot be coded (e.g. "Laparoscopic Appendectomy").

element.comment:
Translation of the source-system-determined procedure code to the study-defined value set may need to be performed by the sponsor.
PRDECOD is the dictionary or the sponsor-defined standardized text description of PRTRT, or the modified topic variable (PRMODIFY), if applicable. This means it is the standardized term for the procedure.

element.name: Modified Procedure Name

cdisc.label: PRMODIFY
cdisc.definition: If the value for PRTERM is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

cdisc.label: PRMODIFY*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap:
Coding translations are conducted by the sponsor.
In FHIR, there's no need to modify the PRTERM. The text which was actually saw/typed (errors and all) is present and the various codes encoding it and the display names for those codes. If there was a need to capture a corrected text that was submitted to a post-coding process, that would be an extension

element.name: Procedure prespecified

cdisc.label: PRPRESP
cdisc.definition: An indication that a specific intervention or a group of interventions is prespecified on a CRF.

cdisc.label: PRPRESP
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Used when a specific procedure is pre-specified on a CRF. Values should be "Y" or null.

element.gap: This likely to be a Questionnaire question than something that would directly be captured in a record. This could possibly be an extension on the Procedure/MedicationAdministration/MedicationStatement.

element.name: Procedure Occurrence

cdisc.label: PROCCUR
cdisc.definition: An indication whether a prespecified procedure (PRTRT) happened when information about the occurrence of a specific intervention is solicited.

cdisc.label: PROCCUR
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). If the response was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTAT with "NOT DONE"
cdisc.definition: Used to record whether a pre-specified procedure occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific procedure is solicited.

definition.value: A code specifying the state of the procedure. Generally, this will be the in-progress or completed state.

comment.value:
The "unknown" code is not to be used to convey other statuses. The "unknown" code should be used when one of the statuses applies, but the authoring system doesn't know the current state of the procedure.
This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

element.comment:
Coding translations are left to the sponsor.
Status of 'not-done', 'entered-in-error' would indicate that it didn't happen, 'active', 'in-progress', 'on-hold', 'completed' would indicate that it did. 'stopped' would indicate that it started, but was abnormally terminated - where that should go depends on the study's definition of 'occur'.

element.name: Procedure Reason for Occur Value

cdisc.label: PRREASOC
cdisc.definition: An explanation of why a scheduled procedure did or did not occur.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRREASOC" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Reason for Occur Value". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable I SDTM domains.

definition.value: The coded reason why the procedure was performed. This may be a coded entity of some type, or may simply be present as text.

comment.value: Use Procedure.reasonCode when a code sufficiently describes the reason. Use Procedure.reasonReference when referencing a resource, which allows more information to be conveyed, such as onset date. Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference are not meant to be duplicative. For a single reason, either Procedure.reasonCode or Procedure.reasonReference can be used. Procedure.reasonCode may be a summary code, or Procedure.reasonReference may be used to reference a very precise definition of the reason using Condition | Observation | Procedure | DiagnosticReport | DocumentReference. Both Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference can be used if they are describing different reasons for the procedure.

definition.value: The justification of why the procedure was performed.

comment.value: It is possible for a procedure to be a reason (such as C-Section) for another procedure (such as an epidural). Other examples include endoscopy for dilatation and biopsy (a combination of diagnostic and therapeutic use). Use Procedure.reasonCode when a code sufficiently describes the reason. Use Procedure.reasonReference when referencing a resource, which allows more information to be conveyed, such as onset date. Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference are not meant to be duplicative. For a single reason, either Procedure.reasonCode or Procedure.reasonReference can be used. Procedure.reasonCode may be a summary code, or Procedure.reasonReference may be used to reference a very precise definition of the reason using Condition | Observation | Procedure | DiagnosticReport | DocumentReference. Both Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference can be used if they are describing different reasons for the procedure.

definition.value: Captures the reason for the current state of the procedure.

comment.value: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "not-done", "suspended" or "aborted". The reason for performing the event at all is captured in reasonCode, not here.

element.comment: Note that reasonReference would need to be turned into a code or string. Reason[x] indicates reason for doing the procedure; statusReason when status=not-done would be reason for non-occurrence

cdisc.label: PRREASND
cdisc.definition: An explanation of why the data are not available.

cdisc.label: PRREASND*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

definition.value: Captures the reason for the current state of the procedure.

comment.value: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "not-done", "suspended" or "aborted". The reason for performing the event at all is captured in reasonCode, not here.

element.name: Prior Procedure

cdisc.label: PRPRIOR
cdisc.definition: Indication the procedure occurred prior to [PRSTTPT] or prior to the date in DM.RFSTDTC.

cdisc.label: PRSTRTPT
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as PRSTRF or PRSTRTPT. When populating PRSTRF, or PRSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field PRPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used.
cdisc.definition: Identifies the start of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable PRSTTPT.

cdisc.label: PRSTRF*
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as PRSTRF or PRSTRTPT. When populating PRSTRF, or PRSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field PRPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

element.comment: Typically, this extension won't exist, or won't be expressed relative to the subjects participation in the study. In such cases, the value for this element will need to be derived by the sponsor through comparision of procedure dates with study participation dates. If available, then the codes 'before-start' and 'before' map to 'true' and the rest map to false.

element.name: Procedure Start Date

cdisc.label: PRSTDAT
cdisc.definition: The date or start date of when the procedure started or was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).

cdisc.label: PRSTDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format
cdisc.definition: Start date/time of the procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

element.comment: FHIR also allows performedString, but there is no way to map that to CDISC. The performedRange mapping is imprecise because it indicates imprecision around the performance rather than a specific start time.

element.name: Ongoing Procedure

cdisc.label: PRONGO
cdisc.definition: Indication the procedure is ongoing when no end date is provided.

cdisc.label: PRENRTPT
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as PRENRF or PRENRTPT. When populating PRENRF, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating PRENRTPT, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When PRONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRENRF should be populated. When PRONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variable PRENRRPT and PRENTPT should be used
cdisc.definition: Identifies the end of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable PRENTPT.

cdisc.label: PRENRF*
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as PRENRF or PRENRTPT. When populating PRENRF, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating PRENRTPT, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When PRONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRENRF should be populated. When PRONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variable PRENRRPT and PRENTPT should be used

definition.value: A code specifying the state of the procedure. Generally, this will be the in-progress or completed state.

comment.value:
The "unknown" code is not to be used to convey other statuses. The "unknown" code should be used when one of the statuses applies, but the authoring system doesn't know the current state of the procedure.
This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

element.comment:
This supports the necessity of separating procedures and medication.
An example of ongoing procedure, "hemodialysis with frequency of three times a week". If the status is 'in-progress'/'active', then it's ongoing.

element.name: Procedure End Date

cdisc.label: PRENDAT
cdisc.definition: The end date of the procedure, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).

cdisc.label: PRENDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format
cdisc.definition: End date/time of the procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

definition.value: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.

comment.value: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old. dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.

element.comment: FHIR also allows performedString, but there is no way to map that to CDISC. The performedRange mapping is imprecise because it indicates imprecision around the performance rather than a specific end time.

element.name: Procedure Indication

cdisc.label: PRINDC
cdisc.definition: The condition, disease, symptom, or disorder that the procedure was used to address or investigate (e.g., why the therapy was taken or administered, why the procedure was performed).

cdisc.label: PRINDC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Denotes the indication for the procedure (e.g., why the procedure was performed).

definition.value: The coded reason why the procedure was performed. This may be a coded entity of some type, or may simply be present as text.

comment.value: Use Procedure.reasonCode when a code sufficiently describes the reason. Use Procedure.reasonReference when referencing a resource, which allows more information to be conveyed, such as onset date. Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference are not meant to be duplicative. For a single reason, either Procedure.reasonCode or Procedure.reasonReference can be used. Procedure.reasonCode may be a summary code, or Procedure.reasonReference may be used to reference a very precise definition of the reason using Condition | Observation | Procedure | DiagnosticReport | DocumentReference. Both Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference can be used if they are describing different reasons for the procedure.

definition.value: The justification of why the procedure was performed.

comment.value: It is possible for a procedure to be a reason (such as C-Section) for another procedure (such as an epidural). Other examples include endoscopy for dilatation and biopsy (a combination of diagnostic and therapeutic use). Use Procedure.reasonCode when a code sufficiently describes the reason. Use Procedure.reasonReference when referencing a resource, which allows more information to be conveyed, such as onset date. Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference are not meant to be duplicative. For a single reason, either Procedure.reasonCode or Procedure.reasonReference can be used. Procedure.reasonCode may be a summary code, or Procedure.reasonReference may be used to reference a very precise definition of the reason using Condition | Observation | Procedure | DiagnosticReport | DocumentReference. Both Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference can be used if they are describing different reasons for the procedure.

element.comment: Note that reasonReference would need to be turned into a code or string.

cdisc.label: PRAENO
cdisc.definition: Identifier for the adverse event that is the indication for this procedure.

cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format

definition.value: Business identifiers assigned to this adverse event by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.

comment.value: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: Related Medical History Event ID

cdisc.label: PRMHNO
cdisc.definition: Identifier for the medical history event that is the indication for this procedure.

cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the eMedical History domain.

element.gap: If FHIR IDs are used for RELREC, then the sponsor should evaluate its use case as necessary prior to mapping.

element.name: Dose Description

cdisc.label: PRDOSTXT
cdisc.definition: Dosing information collected in text form. Examples: <1, 200-400. Not populated when PRDOSE is populated.

element.gap: If FHIR IDs are used for RELREC, then the sponsor should evaluate its use case as necessary prior to mapping.

element.name: Procedure Dose Unit

cdisc.label: PRDOSU
cdisc.definition: The unit for intended dose/amount for PRDOSE, PRDOSTOT, or PRDOSTXT.

cdisc.label: PRDOSU
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Units for PRDOSE, PRDOSTOT, or PRDOSTXT.

element.gap: If FHIR IDs are used for RELREC, then the sponsor should evaluate its use case as necessary prior to mapping.

cdisc.label: PRDOSFRQ
cdisc.definition: The number/amount of the procedure that was given/administered/taken during a specific interval.

definition.value: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

comment.value: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Procedure Route of Administration

cdisc.label: PRROUTE
cdisc.definition: The route of administration of the procedure.

cdisc.label: PRROUTE
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Route of administration for PRTRT.

element.gap: This is a known gap. Procedure Route of Administration interval does NOT exist for 'Procedure'.

cdisc.label: PRLOC
cdisc.definition: A description of the anatomical location of an procedure, such as location of a biopsy.

cdisc.label: PRLOC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Anatomical location of a procedure.

definition.value: Detailed and structured anatomical location information. Multiple locations are allowed - e.g. multiple punch biopsies of a lesion.

comment.value: If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [procedure-targetbodystructure](extension-procedure-targetbodystructure.html).

element.name: Procedure Laterality

cdisc.label: PRLAT
cdisc.definition: Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing side of the body for the procedure administration.

cdisc.label: PRLAT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing laterality.

definition.value: Qualifier to refine the anatomical location. These include qualifiers for laterality, relative location, directionality, number, and plane.

element.comment: This is frequently pre-coordinated into Procedure.bodySite. Multiple qualifiers are possible. Laterality will need to be recognized by code and/or system

element.name: Procedure Directionality

cdisc.label: PRDIR
cdisc.definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.

cdisc.label: PRDIR
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing directionality.

definition.value: Qualifier to refine the anatomical location. These include qualifiers for laterality, relative location, directionality, number, and plane.

element.comment: This is frequently pre-coordinated into Procedure.bodySite. Multiple qualifiers are possible. Directionality will need to be recognized by code and/or system

element.name: Procedure Portion or Totality

cdisc.label: PRPORTOT
cdisc.definition: Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).

cdisc.label: PRPORTOT
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing the distribution, which means arrangement of, apportioning of.

element.gap: Typically this would be pre-coordinated into Procedure.code and would be captured in dosage instructions text for medications. If captured as a separate element, if would need to be an extension.

element.name: Procedure Fasting Status

cdisc.label: PRFAST
cdisc.definition: An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time.

cdisc.label: PRFAST*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This would be handled as an extension. Could propose as standard extension.

element.name: Procedure Intended Dose Regimen

cdisc.label: PRDOSRGM
cdisc.definition: The text description of the (intended) schedule or regimen for the procedure.

cdisc.label: PRDOSRGM
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the procedure.

element.gap: An administration could be based on more than one thing (recommendation, plan, order) and in theory the intended dose would be different for each.

element.name: Procedure Adjusted

cdisc.label: PRDOSADJ
cdisc.definition: An indication whether or not the procedure dose/amount was adjusted.

cdisc.description: When PRDOSADJ is collected, does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM Annotated CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED> When PRADJ is to collected, the sponsor may suit this variable as a SUPPQ.

element.gap: This would be handled as an extension. Would appear on Procedure/MedicationAdministration/MedicationStatement.basedOn. Might consider proposing it as a standard extension.

element.name: Reason for Procedure Adjustment

cdisc.label: PRADJ
cdisc.definition: Description or explanation of why a procedure dose/amount was adjusted.

cdisc.label: PRADJ*
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).

element.gap: This would be handled as an extension. Would appear on Procedure/MedicationAdministration/MedicationStatement.basedOn. Might consider proposing it as a standard extension.

element.name: Completed Procedure

cdisc.label: PRTRTCMP
cdisc.definition: Indication whether the subject completed the intended regimen.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This does not map, directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRTRTCMP" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Treatment Completed".

element.gap: Not all potential mapping/FHIR resources/attributes will be addressed in this implementation guide. All data requires review and analysis to ensure the data is relevant and understood.

element.name: Procedure Interrupted

cdisc.label: PRITRPYN
cdisc.definition: An indication whether the procedure was interrupted.

cdisc.description: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM a CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.

definition.value: A code specifying the state of the procedure. Generally, this will be the in-progress or completed state.

comment.value:
The "unknown" code is not to be used to convey other statuses. The "unknown" code should be used when one of the statuses applies, but the authoring system doesn't know the current state of the procedure.
This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

element.comment: If something is currently interrupted, the status would either be on-hold or stopped. If there was a temporary interruption and the procedure has since resumed or completed, the only way to detect the interruption would be an extension or to review the history.

element.name: Reason Procedure Interrupted

cdisc.label: PRITRPRS
cdisc.definition: An indication of why the intervention was interrupted.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRITRPRS" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Reason intervention Interrupted". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

definition.value: Captures the reason for the current state of the procedure.

comment.value: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "not-done", "suspended" or "aborted". The reason for performing the event at all is captured in reasonCode, not here.

element.comment: If the status is on-hold or stopped, statusReason would convey the reason. If there was a temporary interruption and the procedure has since resumed or completed, the only way to detect the interruption would be an extension or to review the history.

element.name: Procedure Interruption Duration

cdisc.label: PRCINTD
cdisc.definition: The collected duration of the procedure interruption.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRCINTD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Intervention Duration". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

element.gap: This would have to be an extension. Typically, you'd just look at history to see when something was suspended, then resumed.

element.name: Procedure Interruption Duration Units

cdisc.label: PRCINTDU
cdisc.definition: The unit for the collected duration of the procedure interruption.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRITRPD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected procedure interruption duration and the duration unit components and create PRITRPD using ISO 8601.

element.gap: This would have to be part of the previous extension. Typically, reviewing the history of the procedure will indicate if it was suspended and then resumed.

element.name: Procedure Lowest Level Term

cdisc.label: PRLLT
cdisc.definition: MedDRA text description of the Lowest Level Term.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL
cdisc.description: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRLLT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL = "Lower Level Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variable.

definition.value: The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure cannot be coded (e.g. "Laparoscopic Appendectomy").

element.comment:
Procedure Code is performed by the sponsor - not expected to receive this from the site or FHIR.
Procedure.code can contain many codings and at various levels of granularity. Granularity will be determined by reviewing the code system and/or having knowledge of the codes within the same code system (where one code system can express content at multiple granularities).

element.name: Procedure Lowest Level Term Code

cdisc.label: PRLLTCD
cdisc.definition: MedDRA Lowest Level Term code.

cdisc.label: SUPPPR.QVAL

definition.value: The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure cannot be coded (e.g. "Laparoscopic Appendectomy").

element.comment:
Translation of Procedure.code to MeDRA will typically be performed by the sponsor and not provided in FHIR soure data.
Procedure.code can contain as many codings as you like at whatever granularity you like. You would distinguish what granularity it was by looking at the code system and/or having knowledge of the codes within the same code system (where one code system can express content at multiple granularities) Note: Not clear how many of these would be populated for a procedure.

cdisc.label: STUDYID
cdisc.definition: A unique identifier for a study.

cdisc.label: STUDYID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). I the column with the heading SDTMIG Target.
cdisc.definition: Unique identifier for a study.

definition.value: Identifiers assigned to this research study by the sponsor or other systems.

cdisc.label: SITEID
cdisc.definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.

cdisc.label: DM.SITEID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). I the column with the heading SDTMIG Target.
cdisc.definition: Unique identifier for a site within a study.

definition.value: Identifiers assigned to this research study by the sponsor or other systems.

cdisc.label: SUBJID
cdisc.definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.

cdisc.label: DM.SUBJID
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s). I the column with the heading SDTMIG Target.
cdisc.definition: Subject identifier, which must be unique within the study. Often the ID of the subject as recorded on a CRF.

definition.value: Identifiers assigned to this research subject for a study.

element.name: Birth Date

cdisc.label: BRTHDAT
cdisc.definition: A subject's date of birth (with or without the time of birth). The complete Date of Birth is made from the temporal components of Birth Year, Birth Month, Birth Day and Birth Time.

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.
cdisc.definition: Date/time of birth of the subject.

definition.value: The date of birth for the individual.

comment.value: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real DOB is unknown There is a standard extension "patient-birthTime" available that should be used where Time is required (such as in maternity/infant care systems).

element.comment:
There is potential where the birth date can not be collected due to country regulations. In those cases an estimated age may be entered.
Birth time is captured as a standard extension

cdisc.label: BRTHDD
cdisc.definition: Day of birth of the subject in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD).

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.
cdisc.definition: Date/time of birth of the subject.

definition.value: The date of birth for the individual.

comment.value: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real DOB is unknown There is a standard extension "patient-birthTime" available that should be used where Time is required (such as in maternity/infant care systems).

cdisc.label: BRTHMO
cdisc.definition: Month of birth of the subject in an unambiguous date format (e.g., MMM).

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.
cdisc.definition: Date/time of birth of the subject.

definition.value: The date of birth for the individual.

comment.value: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real DOB is unknown There is a standard extension "patient-birthTime" available that should be used where Time is required (such as in maternity/infant care systems).

cdisc.label: BRTHYY
cdisc.definition: The year of birth of the subject in an unambiguous date format (e.g., YYYY).

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.
cdisc.definition: Date/time of birth of the subject.

definition.value: The date of birth for the individual.

comment.value: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real DOB is unknown There is a standard extension "patient-birthTime" available that should be used where Time is required (such as in maternity/infant care systems).

cdisc.label: BRTHTIM
cdisc.definition: The time of birth of the subject in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm)

cdisc.label: BRTHDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.
cdisc.definition: Date/time of birth of the subject.

definition.value: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

comment.value: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Age

cdisc.label: AGE
cdisc.definition: The age of the subject expressed in AGEU.

cdisc.label: AGE
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Age expressed in AGEU. May be derived from RFSTDTC and BRTHDTC, but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases (due to subject privacy concerns).

element.gap:
There is potential where the birth date can not be collected due to country regulations.
Age can be captured either through additional filters, additional transformation, or occasionally looking for information in alternate loacations such as an Observation as a point-in-time assessment, but generally this is simply calculated from birthDate. Specifically, relevant clinical trial documentation will have expectations around units, other code systems and data consistency that may not be met by RWD and conversion and mapping may be necessary.

element.name: Age Units

cdisc.label: AGEU
cdisc.definition: Those units of time that are routinely used to express the age of a person.

cdisc.label: AGEU
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Units associated with AGE.

element.gap: Age can be captured as an Observation as a point-in-time assessment, but generally this is simply calculated from birthDate.

element.name: Demographics Collection Date

cdisc.label: DMDAT
cdisc.definition: The date of collection represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY)

cdisc.label: DMDTC
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission data set, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable BRTHDTC in ISO 860 format.
cdisc.definition: Date/time of demographic data collection.

definition.value: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.comment: This indicates when the Patient resource was last changed, but in practice different pieces of demographics are collected at different times. Review will be required of the history of the patient resource to determine when any particular fact was first asserted.

element.name: Sex

cdisc.label: SEX
cdisc.definition: Sex of the subject as determined by the investigator.

cdisc.label: SEX
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Sex of the subject.

element.gap:
Sex and gender are multi-faceted.concepts. Both FHIR and CDISC standards have a large degree of ambiguity in their definitions for their primary data elements describing a subject’s sex or gender (DM.SEX and Patient.gender). This ambiguity often exists in original source systems. Depending on the use case, the Various facets of sex and gender may be utilized or captured within clinical data.. - physiologic, social, chromosomal, etc. As such, it's not advisable to indicate a mapping where all the facets of sex and gender are ambiguous in both the source and study data standards. Study sponsors and regulators will need to establish policies and look into the quality and nature of the source data as well as the analysis that needs to be performed to determine appropriate mappings.
Extensions such as US core "birth sex" and FHIR core "gender identity" may give more semanticly consistent values, but may not be widely populated Some gender concepts such as physiologic and genetic characteristics may be captured as Observation values rather than as demographics elements on Patient

element.name: Ethnicity

cdisc.label: ETHNIC
cdisc.definition: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.

cdisc.label: ETHNIC
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: The ethnicity of the subject. Sponsors should refer to "Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials" (FDA, September 2005) for guidance regarding the collection of ethnicity (http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/Guidances/ucm126340.htm).

element.gap: There's a U.S. Core extension (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/StructureDefinition-us-core-ethnicity.html) for this to capture ethnicity as required by U.S. legislation. It captures two distinct granularities as well as free text. Depending on the study, the higher or lower granularity might map to ETHNIC and the lower or free text could map to CETHNIC. Other countries use vastly different value sets or prohibit collection. If captured for clinical rather than administrative purposes, this would be an Observation

element.name: Collected Ethnicity

cdisc.label: CETHNIC
cdisc.definition: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.

cdisc.label: SUPPDM.QVAL
cdisc.description: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPDM dataset as the value of SUPPDM.QVAL where SUPPDM.QNAM = "CETHIC" and SUPPDM.QLABEL = "Collected Ethnicity" See SDTMIG v3.2 Section 5, DM Domain. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.

element.gap: There's a U.S. Core extension (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/StructureDefinition-us-core-ethnicity.html) for this to capture ethnicity as required by U.S. legislation. It captures two distinct granularities as well as free text. Depending on the study, the higher or lower granularity might map to ETHNIC and the lower or free text could map to CETHNIC. Other countries use vastly different value sets or prohibit collection. If captured for clinical rather than administrative purposes, this would be an Observation

element.name: Race

cdisc.label: RACE
cdisc.definition: An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (U.S. Center for Disease Control).

cdisc.label: RACE
cdisc.description: The corresponding CDASH Variable(s) map directly to identified SDTM Variable(s).
cdisc.definition: Race of the subject. Sponsors should refer to "Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials" (FDA, September 2005) for guidance regarding the collection of race (http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/Guidances/ucm126340.htm) See Assumption below regarding RACE.

element.gap:
There's a U.S. Core extension (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/StructureDefinition-us-core-race.html) for this to capture race as required by U.S. legislation. In theory, the OMBRace could map to RACE, 'detailed' could map to CRACE and 'text' could map to RACEOTH. However, how appropriate these mappings would be would depend on the study requirements.
Please note: the extension may or may not correspond to the sponsor's requirements and the extension can actually capture race information in 3 different ways, so further mapping would be needed. Other countries use vastly different value sets or prohibit collection. If captured for clinical rather than administrative purposes, this would be an Observation

element.name: Collected Race

cdisc.definition: An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (US Centers for Disease Control).
